text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Ms. Dawson, I need you to take a dictation for me. agent replied Yes, sir... customer asked This should go out as an intra-office memorandum to all employees by this afternoon. Are you ready? agent replied Yes, sir. Go ahead. customer asked Attention all staff... Effective immediately, all office communications are restricted to email correspondence and official memos. The use of Instant Message programs by employees during working hours is strictly prohibited. agent replied Sir, does this apply to intra-office communications only? Or will it also restrict external communications? customer asked It should apply to all communications, not only in this office between employees, but also any outside communications. agent replied But sir, many employees use Instant Messaging to communicate with their clients. customer asked They will just have to change their communication methods. I don't want any - one using Instant Messaging in this office. It wastes too much time! Now, please continue with the memo. Where were we? agent replied This applies to internal and external communications. customer asked Yes. Any employee who persists in using Instant Messaging will first receive a warning and be placed on probation. At second offense, the employee will face termination. Any questions regarding this new policy may be directed to department heads. agent replied Is that all? customer asked Yes. Please get this memo typed up and distributed to all employees before pm.
summary: In order to prevent employees from wasting time on Instant Message programs, decides to terminate the use of those programs and asks Ms. Dawson to send out a memo to all employees by the afternoon.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked I've had it! I am done working for a company that is taking me nowhere! agent replied So what are you gonna do? Just quit? customer asked That's exactly what I am going to do! I have decided to create my own company! I am going to write up a business plan, get some investors and start working for myself! agent replied Have you ever written up a business plan before? customer asked Well, no, it can't be that hard! I mean, all you have to do is explain your business, how you are going to do things and that's it, right? agent replied You couldn't be more wrong! A well written business plan will include an executive summary which highlights the idea of the business in two pages or less. Then you need to describe your company with information such as what type of legal structure it has, history, etc. customer asked Well, that seems easy enough. agent replied Wait, there is more! Then you need to introduce and describe your goods or services. What they are and how they are different from competitors? Then comes the hard part, a market analysis. You need to investigate and analyze hundreds of variables! You need to take into consideration socioeconomic factors from GDP per capita to how many children on average the population has! All this information is useful so that you can move on to your strategy and implementation stage, where you will describe in detail how you will actually execute your idea. customer asked Geez. Is that all? agent replied Almost, the most important piece of information for your investors will be the financial analysis. Here you will calculate and estimate sales, cash flow and profits. After all, people will want to know when they will begin to see a return on their investment! customer asked Umm. I think I ' ll just stick to my old job and save myself all the hassle of trying to start up a business!
summary: abandons the idea of creating a company after explains what a business plan includes. specifies that a well-written business plan includes an executive summary, goods and service description, strategy and implementation, and financial analysis.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Are you going to the demonstration to help stop the spread of nuclear weapons tomorrow, Cleo? agent replied No, Simon. summary: Cleo has no intention to attend the demonstration to help stop the spread of nuclear weapons, because Cleo hates police standing by with tear gas. Simon tries to change Cleo's mind but it doesn't work.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Ah, good morning, Ms. Ross, do come in. agent replied Hello, Mr. Fisher. And we'll charge for the drinks served on a pro-rata basis. customer asked Free, fine, yes. agent replied What type of... um.., equipment, furniture would you like? customer asked Well, let's have.., um... four.., no, no... five tables for our display. Er... we'll bring our own stands. Now, there's an overhead projector and sound system already in the room, I believe? Can you get someone to check that before we come, you know, to see that it's working? agent replied Oh, of course, the technician will be with you when you're setting everything up. Oh, the seats in that room have flap-over desk tops, will that be all right? customer asked Yes, yes, that's fine, sure. agent replied You say you've sent out the invitations, any idea how many people there'll be? Urn... I think you know there's... the capacity for the room is about but is ideal. customer asked Yes, ah... the problem is that we won't know exactly how many there'll be until shortly before. agent replied Can you let me know definitely by Thursday? customer asked Mm... no. But I'll have a rough idea and we'll budget for the number I give you then. We've sent out invitations... agent replied customer asked Yes, well, in theory that meant that there could be people. agent replied Yes, but the room won't... customer asked But of course, haha... I don't expect more than about to come. agent replied But what if they do? This room is the only one we have that day--there's a wedding reception in the banqueting rooms, so we... customer asked Well, in that case, I suppose...
summary: Ms. Ross helps Mr. Fisher make arrangements for a presentation. Mr. Fisher decides to serve a pre-lunch snack buffet and designs the room setting. Mr. Fisher isn't sure about how many people to come and Ms. Ross is worried that there might be too many people because the room is small.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked What are the main differences between this country and your country? agent replied Well, in Russia, everything happens very fast. People talk quickly, they drive their cars too fast, the good deals go by really quickly...but here in Canada, it seems like people are a little more relaxed. customer asked Is that true for everything? agent replied No, of course not. In Russia, going to the bank can take hours. The same is true for the post office and the supermarket. In Canada, however, these places are pretty easy to get through quickly. customer asked So, what is it that makes some things go either faster or slower compared to us here in Canada? I was born and raised here, so I guess I don't notice these things. I've also never been outside the country before. agent replied I think the people in Russia are fast movers by nature, at least in the big cities. Public places are still very slow because they haven't tried to do business any differently than they used to. customer asked But in Canada, it's the opposite? agent replied Right. The government here does a great job of solving problems and using new technology to make businesses work better. But I think Canadians are just more calm in general than Russians are... and they're definitely more relaxed than Americans! customer asked Well, I agree with you about that last part!
summary: and are talking about the differences between Russia and Canada. tells that almost everything in Russia happens fast while it's the opposite in Canada.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Excuse me. Can you tell me how to get started using these machines? agent replied Of course. Are you a new member here? customer asked Yes. agent replied Welcome. My name is Johnson. customer asked Nice to meet you. agent replied Do you have any experience using weights? customer asked No, I don't. So I need some help. agent replied Well, first it is important to go through a good stretch. You must warm up properly so that you don't hurt yourself on the machines. customer asked Yes, I know that. Derek just led me through the warm up in the aerobics room. So I'm ready, I think. I can start using the machines. agent replied Alright. Great. Then we must get a card for you. customer asked What do you mean--a membership card? I already have one. agent replied No. Not that. I mean a training card. The card allows you to keep track of how much weight you use on each machine. Here, let me show you. customer asked I'm ready. agent replied Now, you can see that on this card there are all the machines listed. So, when you go through the series of twelve machines, you enter in the number of repetitions you do. And you also enter in the weight at which you set the machine. customer asked I see. So this card helps me to keep track of my progress. agent replied Yes. And it also reminds you what is a suitable weight for each machine. Today, I will go through the machines with you one by one. I will show you how to use them. And we will determine what is a good starting weight for you. customer asked Alright. Great. agent replied So you write your name and member number at the top of the card. And then, after you exercise each time, you file the card here. customer asked Great. Why don't we start on the machines? agent replied Are you alright? Can you do more? customer asked I'm sorry. I know there are still seven machines. But I'm exhausted. agent replied That's okay. Don't worry. It's important not to push yourself. Especially not at the beginning. customer asked What can I do though? I don't know the proper settings for the rest of the machines. agent replied We can just go through them next time. It's no problem. Really. The most important thing is to know your limits. So if you feel burned out now, it is good to stop. Because if you strain a muscle or hurt your back, then you won't be able to exercise for a couple weeks. Right? customer asked Yes. I suppose it's best to stop.
summary: Johnson is teaching how to use the training machines. He introduces a training card that allows to keep track of the weight used on each machine. is exhausted when there are still machines left. Johnson suggests stop to train and go through the rest of the machines next time.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Simon, how does it feel to be retired? agent replied Well, not so bad. customer asked How have you been spending your time? agent replied I have been spending more time with my family. I've also traveled a bit, you know, off season when everywhere is less crowded and hotels cost less. customer asked Great. agent replied You know I haven't stopped work completely. customer asked Yes, could you tell us more about this? agent replied I'm on a scheme that's called phased retirement; I had a six-month break from work, after that I could apply for project work with the company I used to work for. customer asked How does the scheme work? agent replied Well, it's a trial at the moment. Instead of hiring temporary stuff, the company advertises posts on its website that retired employees like myself can access. customer asked What sort of works advertised? agent replied Well, all sorts of things, really. Administrative work and more specialized work, the sort of thing I can do. Some of the projects can last five or six months, and others can just be a couple of days. I can decide more or less when to work. So I can manage my own time. customer asked I can see it's good for you. What is your company get out of this? agent replied Well, I still have all my old contacts at work, so I know who to contact to get something done. The company gets flexibility, too. Once the job's over, that's it. I'm not on their books any more.
summary: Simon tells that he is on a scheme called phased retirement during which he had a six-month break from work, and after that he could apply for projects of the company he used to work for but manage his own time. thinks it's good for Simon.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Hey, Susan. Have you got a sec? I have some questions about my paycheck. agent replied You bet, Emily. First of all, what is this FICA, and SUI Y tax, and why are there deductions both for Medicare and for my health insurance plan? agent replied OK, let's start from the top of your pay stub. This number here represents your gross pay. Then here we have a series of deductions. First off are the federal ones. FICA stands for Federal Insurance Contribution Act, or something like that. It's your federal income tax. And then there's Social Security and Medicare, which are both federal programs to help you out after you retire or if you were unable to work. customer asked All right, I see. So the Medicare isn't actually a health insurance I can use now. agent replied That's right. Below the federal deductions are the state deductions. There's the state income tax, and then this SUI/SDI tax you were asking about is paying into an unemployment and disability fund that our state has set up, but you can see it's a pretty small quantity that they take. customer asked Yeah, I don't mind giving them a dollar fifty for that. So there are two separate income taxes,one at a state level and one at a federal level? agent replied That's right. Not all states have an income tax. Some use higher property taxes or sales taxes instead. customer asked I see. All right, well I think everything else I can figure out on my own. The deductions for health insurance and my are pretty self-explanatory. Thanks for your help, Susan. agent replied No problem! All those deductions do add up, and nobody's net pay is as high as they'd like. I can understand why you'd want some explanation. customer asked Yeah, I guess it's the same in the UK, I just never paid much attention. See you later!
summary: Emily is asking Susan some questions about her paycheck. Susan tells her that there are two separate income taxes-federal deductions, helping people out after they retire or if they were unable to workand, and state deductions, paying into an unemployment and disability fund that the state has set up.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Hey Sarah, are you all right? You look upset. agent replied As a matter of fact, I am a bit upset. I just came out of a meeting and it didn't go very well. customer asked What happened? agent replied No one would listen to any of my suggestions. Instead, they just kept arguing with each other. customer asked Who was chairing the meeting? agent replied Bob. customer asked Well, I can tell you from experience that Bob might come off a little strong sometimes. agent replied That's exactly what happened! He kept interrupting everyone with his own suggestions and did not want to hear what others had to say. Then he expected everyone to agree with him. customer asked What was the meeting about? agent replied We were trying to come up with ideas to streamline the office's workflow to make it more efficient. customer asked It's ironic that the meeting was anything but efficient. agent replied Exactly. I had tons of ideas that I wanted to share, but they just wouldn't let me finish. What should I have done to get my point across? customer asked You have to keep things short and sweet. When you get a chance to speak, try not to get into too many unnecessary details. agent replied Short and sweet? But what if I have to explain something complicated? customer asked You can always bring up the main points during the meeting and speak to those who are directly involved after the meeting. Not everyone needs to know all that information. agent replied That's a good idea, I think I will try that at the next meeting.
summary: Sarah is upset because Bob kept interrupting everyone else during a meeting, making it impossible to elaborate her ideas. gives Sarah a useful tip to get her point across at the next meeting.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Hi! What are you watching? agent replied It's a program about islam. It's very interesting. customer asked Wow! Unfortunately, so many people go on the haj each year that there are often stamped and people get killed. customer asked I heard about that. The pilgrims must walk around a large, sacred black stone. agent replied That's right. That's when accidents often happen. The Saudi government tries to limit the number of pilgrims, to reduce the chances of accidents. customer asked Pilgrimages are common in many faiths. agent replied Yes. In England, Christian pilgrims might go to Canterbury and many Christians go to the Vatican on pilgrimages. customer asked Isn't there a place in france where people go to get healed? agent replied I think that place is Lourdes. There are many stories of people being healed after visiting there. customer asked Do you think that there is something magical about that place? agent replied Personally. I think that people believe they will be healed and that faith causes a change in their mind that cures them. I don't think place is magical in any way.
summary: and talk about pilgrims around the world, including Muslims' pilgrimage to mecca and Christians' pilgrimage to Canterbury or Vatican. thinks faith heals people instead of magical places.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Good evening, Pete. I trust you had a nice siesta. agent replied Yes. text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Vet, can you tell us what you usually do to deal with stress and depression? agent replied I eat a cucumber and go to bed. I figure it's a healthy alternative to chocolate. customer asked Do you ever feel that having a baby has stopped you from your goals or dreams? agent replied I always wanted to be a cheerleader, and that won't happen, I also miss out on a lot of freedom. No one makes me come home on time, and I probably wouldn't normally, but I now have a responsibility to my baby. customer asked What is your favorite part of having a daughter? agent replied It is so hard to narrow it down to one thing. I love the way she looks at me and admires me. She lets me feel so much love. She is innocent and pure. The best part of being with her is watching her go through every stage knowing there is somebody who loves her. customer asked What are your plans for the future? agent replied I am going to be a lawyer. Down the road, I hope to move out of Utah. customer asked What are some of your future goals and dreams? agent replied I want to start small. First and foremost, I am looking forward to graduating from high school. I eventually want to get married. Having a father figure in my baby's life is important to me because I missed out on that. I want to start modeling again, and I hope to keep up with my dancing and singing. It is also important to keep family traditions for me and my baby. customer asked What is your favorite quote? agent replied What happens in the dark will come out in the light. There is nothing that you can try to hide without it coming out sometime. It is important not to hide anything from yourself or anybody else. customer asked What advice would you give teens? agent replied Take things slow, and be a kid as long as you possibly can. Don't expect everything to be perfect, and make decisions for yourself. Live life to the fullest. Love yourself first, and everything else will fall into place.
summary: Vet tells her own experience as a young mother and how her daughter changes her. Then she tells her future goals and dreams. And she also gives teens advice.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Police in North London are treating as murder the death of a man thought to be in his forties whose body was found in a pedestrian subway in Neasden. He was found in the underpass, the pedestrian way, under the North Circular Road. Death was due to multiple head injuries. We understand that there may have been two girls and a man who was drunk in close proximity to the entrance to the subway, who may have seen the man walking in that direction, or any attacker who may have been following him. customer asked About what time would you think that they were there? agent replied Just after half past one to a quarter past two. customer asked Then in that case the gap you have is really quite short. It's only more or less half a hour or forty minutes. agent replied In fact, yes, as short as that. customer asked And how far away from the Neasden underpass was the drinking club? agent replied Fifty meters. customer asked And at the moment you know of no other people in the area whom you want to talk to, other than the drunken man and the two women who were seen with him or near him at some time? agent replied Yes. The club closed at half past one and there may have been other people who left the club who went that way. We understand that there were also minicab drivers parked in the area who may have seen something as well. customer asked As it is, I take it you haven't been able to identify them. agent replied No, not at this stage. customer asked Well, thank you very much.
summary: John Day describes known details of a murder case which happened in a pedestrian subway at midnight and answers questions to tell what he know about the case. But he hasn't be able to identify more, even he knows three witnesses.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Morgan, can I ask you a question? agent replied sure, what is it? customer asked I was just wondering if many Chinese people take their leftover food home from a restaurant. agent replied in most cities in China, doggie bags are quite uncommon. customer asked what happen to all the leftover food? agent replied it usually goes to the dump. customer asked that seems like an awful waste! text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked I swear I will never shop at a street market in China. It's a terrible place full of excellent profiteers! Last Sunday I went to a nearby market. It was on open-air fair. I chanced upon this bag and bought it on the spot, without even trying to strike a bargain. I paid one hundred and twenty. And just now I was told by my Chinese colleagues I bought it overpriced. I could have talked my way to thirty. agent replied is that so? I'm afraid people here will not take pity on unlucky guys like you. Bargaining has always been an indispensable procedure in business deals. It's the norm of free trade. The seller sets a preposterous price, and the buyer tries his best to bring it down, until a compromise is reached. Yet you ignored the process. No wonder you ended up easy prey. customer asked but don't you think it annoying to overcharge the customers by such a handsome margin? agent replied of course, that's something really irritating. And the only way to avoid being trapped is to know in advance about the real worth of the stuff. I recommend you to consult the price tags in the supermarket first. And then you may negotiate for a fair deal.
summary: suggests Harry consult the price tags in the supermarket first and then negotiate for a fair deal after Harry bought a bag overpriced and got a terrible feeling.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Hi, Ann, welcome back. How's your trip to the states? agent replied Very busy. I had a lot of meetings. So, of course, I didn't have much time to see New York. customer asked What a pity. Actually I have a trip there myself next week. agent replied Do you? Then take my advice. Do the well-being in the air program. It really works. customer asked Oh, I read about that in a magazine. You say it works? agent replied Yes. I did the program on the flight to the States. And when I arrived in New York, I didn't have any problem. No jet leg at all. On the way back I didn't do it, and I felt terrible. customer asked You are joking. agent replied Not at all. It really made a lot of difference. customer asked Hmm...So, what did you do? agent replied Well, I didn't drink any alcohol or coffee and I didn't eat any meat or rich food. I drink a lot of water and fruit juice and I eat the meals on the well-being menu. They are lighter. They have fish, vegetables and noodles, for example. And I did some of the exercises in the program. customer asked Exercises? On a plane? agent replied Yes. I didn't do many, of course. There isn't much space on the plane. customer asked How many passengers did the exercises? agent replied Not many. customer asked And how much champagne did they drink? agent replied A lot. It was more popular than mineral water. customer asked So, basically it's a choice. Mineral water and exercises or champagne and jet lag. agent replied That's right. It's a difficult choice.
summary: Ann suggests take well-being in the air programme including drinking mineral water and exercising so that could get over jet lag.

text: this is the conversation between customer and agent. customer asked Good evening and welcome to this week's Business World, the program for and about business people. Tonight, we have Mr. Steven Kayne, who has just taken over and established bicycle shop. Tell us, Mr. Kayne, what made you want to run yourown store? agent replied Well, I always loved racing bikes and fixing them. When I was working full-time as a salesman for a big company, I seldom had time to enjoy my hobby. I knew then that as soon as I had enough money to get my own business going, I'll do it. I had my heart set on it and I didn't let anything stand in my way. When I went down to the bank and got a business loan, I knew I'd love being myown boss. Now my time is my own. I open the store when I want and leave when I want. customer asked You mean you don't keep regular hours? agent replied Well, the sign on my store says the hours are ten to six, but if business isslower than usual, I can just lock up and take off early. customer asked Have you hired any employees to work with you yet? agent replied Yeah, a couple of friends of mine who love biking as much as I do. They help me out a few days a week. It's great because we play cards or just sit around and talk when there are no customers. customer asked Thank you, Mr. Kayne. We wish you success in your new business.
summary: Mr. Steven Kayne is invited to share his experience of establishing a bicycle shop by a business program.
